properties.Name: NonforfeitureOptionType
properties.Description:
The nonforfeiture options policyholders can select.

Ex:
- Cash Surrender Value
- Extended Term Option
- Reduced Paid-Up Option

CASH SURRENDER VALUE
The amount of cash due an insured who surrenders the insurance policy.

A table of cash surrender values is included in every permanent life insurance policy.

Insurers are required to make cash surrender values available for ordinary whole life insurance after the first three policy years and after five years for industrial life insurance.

Many states allow the insurers to postpone payment of cash surrender values up to six months after policyholders request payment ('delayed payment provision').

Whole life insurance combines insurance protection with a savings or accumulation component known as the cash value of the insurance policy, which builds over the life of the policy.

Whole life insurance plans are credited with a specific guaranteed rate of interest, which is credited to the insurance policy on a regular basis and continues to grow.

The taxation of accumulated values received when a policyholder surrenders a policy is determined by their cost basis.   The excess of proceeds over the cost of the policy dividends received, less any policy loan and less extra premiums paid for supplementary benefits.

Endowment policy proceeds, even those left with the company at maturity under an interest-only option, will be partially taxed under the rule of constructive receipt.   The taxable amount will be the excess of the proceeds over the premiums paid.

EXTENDED TERM OPTION
The policy's cash value is used to purchase a term insurance policy in an amount equal to the original policy's face value for as long as a period as the cash value will purchase.

Then the term insurance expires, there is no more protection. 

All supplemental benefits included with the original policy are dropped.

REDUCED PAID-UP OPTION
The policyholder does not pay any more premiums but still retains some amount of life insurance.

The policyowner does not pay any more premiums but still retains some amount of life insurance.

Essentially the cash value is used as the premium for a single-premium whole life policy at a lesser face amount than the original policy.

The paid-up policy is the same kind as the original, but for a lesser amount of coverage (see relationship to Life Insurance Policy entities for this new policy).  

The new paid-up policy is computed as a single-premium policy at the attained-age rate.  
Any term insurance rider and disability or accidental death benefits from the original policy are excluded when the amount of paid-up life insurance is calculated.

Once the paid-up policy has been issued and is in effect, the new face value remains the same for the life of the policy, which builds cash values.

Columns.Name: NonforfeitureOptionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Nonforfeiture Option Type.

Columns.Name: NonforfeitureOptionTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of a Nonforfeiture Option Type.

Columns.Name: NonforfeitureOptionTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of a Nonforfeiture Option Type.

Properties.Description:
The nonforfeiture options policyholders can select.

Ex:
- Cash Surrender Value
- Extended Term Option
- Reduced Paid-Up Option

CASH SURRENDER VALUE
The amount of cash due an insured who surrenders the insurance policy.

A table of cash surrender values is included in every permanent life insurance policy.

Insurers are required to make cash surrender values available for ordinary whole life insurance after the first three policy years and after five years for industrial life insurance.

Many states allow the insurers to postpone payment of cash surrender values up to six months after policyholders request payment ('delayed payment provision').

Whole life insurance combines insurance protection with a savings or accumulation component known as the cash value of the insurance policy, which builds over the life of the policy.

Whole life insurance plans are credited with a specific guaranteed rate of interest, which is credited to the insurance policy on a regular basis and continues to grow.

The taxation of accumulated values received when a policyholder surrenders a policy is determined by their cost basis.   The excess of proceeds over the cost of the policy dividends received, less any policy loan and less extra premiums paid for supplementary benefits.

Endowment policy proceeds, even those left with the company at maturity under an interest-only option, will be partially taxed under the rule of constructive receipt.   The taxable amount will be the excess of the proceeds over the premiums paid.

EXTENDED TERM OPTION
The policy's cash value is used to purchase a term insurance policy in an amount equal to the original policy's face value for as long as a period as the cash value will purchase.

Then the term insurance expires, there is no more protection. 

All supplemental benefits included with the original policy are dropped.

REDUCED PAID-UP OPTION
The policyholder does not pay any more premiums but still retains some amount of life insurance.

The policyowner does not pay any more premiums but still retains some amount of life insurance.

Essentially the cash value is used as the premium for a single-premium whole life policy at a lesser face amount than the original policy.

The paid-up policy is the same kind as the original, but for a lesser amount of coverage (see relationship to Life Insurance Policy entities for this new policy).  

The new paid-up policy is computed as a single-premium policy at the attained-age rate.  
Any term insurance rider and disability or accidental death benefits from the original policy are excluded when the amount of paid-up life insurance is calculated.

Once the paid-up policy has been issued and is in effect, the new face value remains the same for the life of the policy, which builds cash values.
